description.narrative: The country and its citizens benefit from the reconstructed transport infrastructure, its increased resilience to floods and improved floods mitigation potential

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Number of reconstructed bridges/culverts damaged by the floods (at least 4 in total length of 161,67m)
Number and length of recovered roads by category of road and regions (at least 16 km of local roads in four affected municipalities)
At least one landslide on regional/local roads stabilized
# of Knowledge products and public awareness raising material
Guidance document for incorporation of the “built back better” in place

comment.narrative:
42.8 % of total damages and losses occurred in the infrastructure sector due to the floods that occured in 2015 . Increased risk and vulnerability of transport infrastructure through instability of sloping terrain that may cause further landslides, the occurrence of aftershocks following an earthquake, and possible occurrence of further intensive rainfall and flooding
Limited knowledge about the contemporary approaches for recovery of infrastructure in accordance with the ‘build back better’ principles. The current design approaches often do not take the importance of enhancing resilience of the infrastructure into consideration

1. Almost 40,000 people from five (out of eight selected) flood-sensitive municipalities in the Pelagonija and Bregalnica regions benefit from the restored priority transport infrastructure 2. A baseline on the current levels of community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs is established through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll

1. As a response to the widespread 2015-floods that occurred in country’s east, southeast and Pelagonija regions, UNDP launched all eight transport infrastructure reconstruction projects that are part of the EU Flood Recovery Programme. Five out of eight projects have been fully or nearly completed producing considerable benefits for a population of almost 40,000 people. The transport infrastructure restored in line with the ‘build back better’ principles helps restore connectivity, reduces travel time and increases resilience to future floods of communities in the following five municipalities: a) Cesinovo – Oblesevo (over 7,000 people benefiting from a restored bridge/culvert on a regional road); b) Probistip (over 16,000 people benefiting from a stabilized landslide on a regional road); c) Novaci (3,500 people benefiting from reconstructed local road with length of 2 km); d) Mogila (almost 7,000 people benefiting from reconstructed local transport infrastructure of 13 km); e) Konce (3,500 people benefiting from reconstructed local road of 6.5 km). The size of positively affected population is expected to double once the three other ongoing projects are completed.
2. Through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll the baseline on the current levels of community awareness on flood risks, flood recovery needs and the role of the EU Flood Recovery Programme in addressing the recovery needs has been established. These findings informed the design and implementation of the ongoing awareness raising programme targeting key communities and beneficiaries. Similar survey at the end of the programme will measure the effectiveness of the communication and awareness raising work in the selected priority flood-sensitive regions.

1. Almost 40,000 people from five (out of eight selected) flood-sensitive municipalities in the Pelagonija and Bregalnica regions benefit from the restored priority transport infrastructure 2. A baseline on the current levels of community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs is established through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll

1. As a response to the widespread 2015-floods that occurred in country’s east, southeast and Pelagonija regions, UNDP launched all eight transport infrastructure reconstruction projects that are part of the EU Flood Recovery Programme. Five out of eight projects have been fully or nearly completed producing considerable benefits for a population of almost 40,000 people. The transport infrastructure restored in line with the ‘build back better’ principles helps restore connectivity, reduces travel time and increases resilience to future floods of communities in the following five municipalities: a) Cesinovo – Oblesevo (over 7,000 people benefiting from a restored bridge/culvert on a regional road); b) Probistip (over 16,000 people benefiting from a stabilized landslide on a regional road); c) Novaci (3,500 people benefiting from reconstructed local road with length of 2 km); d) Mogila (almost 7,000 people benefiting from reconstructed local transport infrastructure of 13 km); e) Konce (3,500 people benefiting from reconstructed local road of 6.5 km). The size of positively affected population is expected to double once the three other ongoing projects are completed.
2. Through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll the baseline on the current levels of community awareness on flood risks, flood recovery needs and the role of the EU Flood Recovery Programme in addressing the recovery needs has been established. These findings informed the design and implementation of the ongoing awareness raising programme targeting key communities and beneficiaries. Similar survey at the end of the programme will measure the effectiveness of the communication and awareness raising work in the selected priority flood-sensitive regions.

• Almost 80,000 people from the eight selected flood-sensitive municipalities in the Pelagonija and Bregalnica regions benefit from the restored priority transport infrastructure • Changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs and options are documented as part of the second comprehensive survey/opinion poll • Lessons learnt and guidance document for integrating the “build back better” concept into the engineering designs for the transport infrastructure is prepared and shared with all relevant stakeholders

• The EU Floods Recovery Programme – Reconstruction and Rehabilitation of Transport Infrastructure was completed in a timely fashion and in line with the earlier developed recovery plans and design documentation. Almost 80,000 people from the eight selected flood-sensitive municipalities in the Pelagonija and Bregalnica regions benefit from the recovered/improved infrastructure as a result of the restored connectivity, reduced travel time and increased resilience to future floods (e.g., because of improved discharge capacity of bridges). Communities and businesses from the following municipalities already enjoy the benefits of the infrastructure recovered in line with the ‘build back better’ principles: a) Cesinovo – Oblesevo (7,500 people benefiting from a restored bridge/culvert on a regional road); b) Probistip (over 16,000 people benefiting from a stabilized landslide on a regional road); c) Novaci (3,500 people benefiting from reconstructed local road with length of 2 km); d) Mogila (almost 7,000 people benefiting from reconstructed local transport infrastructure of 13 km); e) Konce (3,500 people benefiting from reconstructed road of 6.5 km), e) Delcevo (over 17,000 people benefiting from a reconstructed bridge on a regional road); f) Zrnovci (over 3,200 people benefiting from a reconstructed bridge on a regional road); and g) Sveti Nikole (app. 18,500 people benefiting from a reconstructed bridge/culvert on a regional road).
• Analysis and reporting about changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and recovery needs will be completed under the ongoing complementary EU-funded project focusing on recovery of water infrastructure, in line with the earlier decision of the Delegation of the EU. The opinion poll will intend to capture important changes in floods awareness and knowledge that are relevant for both components of the programme (Transport and Water infrastructure), and therefore will be completed as part of the Water Infrastructure component, taking into account its longer lifespan.
• Overcoming the multiple and multilayer complex challenges affecting project implementation (e.g., legal and institutional, quality of designs, contractor performance) has generated for the project valuable experiences and lessons that were summarized in two documents: a) final project report; b) guidance document/manual for integrating the ‘build back better’ concept into engineering designs. Both documents were developed and communicated with the key stakeholders, securing sound basis for future replication of the ‘build back better’ approach in infrastructure recovery.

• Almost 80,000 people from the eight selected flood-sensitive municipalities in the Pelagonija and Bregalnica regions benefit from the restored priority transport infrastructure • Changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs and options are documented as part of the second comprehensive survey/opinion poll • Lessons learnt and guidance document for integrating the “build back better” concept into the engineering designs for the transport infrastructure is prepared and shared with all relevant stakeholders

• The EU Floods Recovery Programme – Reconstruction and Rehabilitation of Transport Infrastructure was completed in a timely fashion and in line with the earlier developed recovery plans and design documentation. Almost 80,000 people from the eight selected flood-sensitive municipalities in the Pelagonija and Bregalnica regions benefit from the recovered/improved infrastructure as a result of the restored connectivity, reduced travel time and increased resilience to future floods (e.g., because of improved discharge capacity of bridges). Communities and businesses from the following municipalities already enjoy the benefits of the infrastructure recovered in line with the ‘build back better’ principles: a) Cesinovo – Oblesevo (7,500 people benefiting from a restored bridge/culvert on a regional road); b) Probistip (over 16,000 people benefiting from a stabilized landslide on a regional road); c) Novaci (3,500 people benefiting from reconstructed local road with length of 2 km); d) Mogila (almost 7,000 people benefiting from reconstructed local transport infrastructure of 13 km); e) Konce (3,500 people benefiting from reconstructed road of 6.5 km), e) Delcevo (over 17,000 people benefiting from a reconstructed bridge on a regional road); f) Zrnovci (over 3,200 people benefiting from a reconstructed bridge on a regional road); and g) Sveti Nikole (app. 18,500 people benefiting from a reconstructed bridge/culvert on a regional road).
• Analysis and reporting about changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and recovery needs will be completed under the ongoing complementary EU-funded project focusing on recovery of water infrastructure, in line with the earlier decision of the Delegation of the EU. The opinion poll will intend to capture important changes in floods awareness and knowledge that are relevant for both components of the programme (Transport and Water infrastructure), and therefore will be completed as part of the Water Infrastructure component, taking into account its longer lifespan.
• Overcoming the multiple and multilayer complex challenges affecting project implementation (e.g., legal and institutional, quality of designs, contractor performance) has generated for the project valuable experiences and lessons that were summarized in two documents: a) final project report; b) guidance document/manual for integrating the ‘build back better’ concept into engineering designs. Both documents were developed and communicated with the key stakeholders, securing sound basis for future replication of the ‘build back better’ approach in infrastructure recovery.
